discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
From EC Council: On Windows Server OSes, the log files are stored by default in %SystemDrive%\inetpub\logs\LogFiles

IIS log files are stored by default in the %SystemDrive%\inetpub\logs\LogFiles folder of your IIS server. The folder is configured in the Directory property on the Logging page for either the server or an individual site

questions.question_text: What is the default IIS log location?

Charles has accidentally deleted an important file while working on his Mac computer. He wants to recover the deleted file as it contains some of his crucial business secrets. Which of the following tool will help Charles?

discussion.content:
The correct answer is C. FileSalvage.
FileSalvage is a data recovery tool specifically designed for Mac OS X, which can help Charles recover his deleted file. It scans the drive for deleted files and attempts to recover them.
The other options are not suitable for this scenario:
A. Xplico is a network forensics analysis tool, not a file recovery tool.
B. Colasoft's Capsa is a network protocol analyzer, not a file recovery tool.
D. DriveSpy is a tool for analyzing and recovering data from Windows drives, not Mac OS X drives.
C. FileSalvage is an extremely powerful Macintosh application for exploring and recovering deleted files from a drive or volume.

questions.question_text: Which file is a sequence of bytes organized into blocks understandable by the system's linker?

Smith, a forensic examiner, was analyzing a hard disk image to find and acquire deleted sensitive files. He stumbled upon a $Recycle.Bin folder in the root directory of the disk. Identify the operating system in use.

discussion.content: NT 6.0 and Higher. Vista and above. C is correct

https://bookshelf.vitalsource.com/reader/books/9781635676969/pageid/443
Module 05: Defeating Anti-forensics Tecniques / LO#02: Discuss Data Deletion and Recycle Bin Forensics / Recycle Bin in Windows
Page 444:

The storage location of Recycle Bin depends on type of OS and file system
Recycle Bin storage location on FAT file systems:
On older FAT file systems (Windows 98 and prior), it is located in Drive:\RECYCLED
Recycle Bin storage location on NTFS file systems:
On Windows 2000, NT, and XP it is located in Drive:\RECYCLER\<SID>
On Windows Vista and later versions, it is located in Drive:\$Recycle.Bin\<SID>

--> Windows 8.1

Selected Answer: C
Windows Vista and later: $Recycle.Bin
Windows XP and earlier: Recycler

Selected Answer: C
From EC Council: In Windows Vista and later versions, the deleted files are renamed by the OS using the following format: $ [...] The $R and $I files are located at C:\$Recycle.Bin\<USER SID>\

according to CHFI V10 book, On Windows Vista and later versions, it is located in Drive:\$Recycle.Bin\<SID>

Answer is Windows 8.1

ItÂ´s supposed that Drive\RECYCLER is the answer for XP and $Recycle.Bin for vista and later versions. I suppose is correct in the context but not in the content according to the CHFI V9 Module 5 page 472

choices.B: RIYG6VR.doc is the name of the doc file deleted from the system
choices.A: It is a doc file deleted in seventh sequential order
choices.D: It is a deleted doc file
choices.C: It is file deleted from R drive

questions.question_text: Jason discovered a file named $RIYG6VR.doc in the C:\$Recycle.Bin\<USER SID>\ while analyzing a hard disk image for the deleted data. What inferences can he make from the file name?

discussion.content:
The correct answer is D. It is a deleted doc file.
The file name $RIYG6VR.doc is a renamed file in the $Recycle.Bin folder, which indicates that it's a deleted file. The original file name has been changed to a random name by Windows when it was deleted.
Here's what we can infer from the file name:
The $R prefix indicates that the file was deleted from the C: drive (not the R: drive).
The IYG6VR part is a random generated name by Windows.
The .doc extension suggests that the original file was a Microsoft Word document.
